column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. Fully-vaccinated travellers entering Brunei must take an ART upon arrival (Day 1), and again on Day 2 and Day 3 after arriving in Brunei. Self-isolation is no longer required if the ART results are negative. You must pay $40 BND for the three ART kits given to you on arrival.
Travellers who are not fully-vaccinated are only permitted to enter Brunei if they can verify that they are medically exempted from receiving a COVID-19 vaccination. Unvaccinated travellers will need to follow the non-Travel Green List Countries travel protocols (see Entry from a non-green list country below). They are required to perform an ART upon arrival and RT-PCR test on Day 3.
All travellers into Brunei must;
• be fully vaccinated with 2 doses unless they can show proof of a medical exemption from having the COVID-19 vaccination (under 18s travelling with a group of vaccinated adults will follow the vaccinated protocols)
• submit an Arrival Declaration form on the PMO travel portal no more than 24 hours prior to departure.
• download and register on the BruHealth App prior to departure (see Data Collection).
• make payment for the relevant post arrival COVID tests depending on your vaccination or recovery status and obtain a payment receipt which states the name and passport number of the traveller
• show to their airline at check-in a negative COVID-19 RT PCR test obtained within 48 hours of departure, or an ART obtained within 24 hours of departure (those with recovery certificates do not need to do a pre-departure test).
From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempt from providing a pre-travel negative COVID-19 test and will only have to take an ART on arrival. They must have a certificate as proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 90 days.
column3:
Quarantine requirement at government designated site. From 6 May onwards, fully vaccinated visitors to Brunei from will not need to isolate on arrival. Only unvaccinated travellers will need to undergo self-isolation at a suitable accommodation (home residence or hotel accommodation) until their receive a negative result for the post arrival RT-PCR test.
From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempted from undergoing mandatory self-isolation. They must provide proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 90 days.
On arrival in Brunei, it is mandatory to use the BruHealth app to record test results.
Travellers who are not fully-vaccinated are only permitted to enter Brunei if they can verify that they are medically exempted from receiving a COVID-19 vaccination. Unvaccinated travellers will need to follow the non-Travel Green List Countries travel protocols (see Entry from a non-green list country below).
They are required to perform an ART upon arrival and RT-PCR test on Day 3. They are also required to undergo self-isolation until a negative RT-PCR result is obtained. Travellers will be charged $100 BND for both ART and RT-PCR.
See the Brunei Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) website for further information, or contact the Brunei High Commission.
column4:
From 6 May 2022, Brunei will no longer categorise countries and will allow fully vaccinated passengers to make non-essential travel by air to and from any countries without requiring an Entry Travel Pass. (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 status below for definition of fully vaccinated).
o enter Brunei, a traveller is considered fully vaccinated if they have received two doses of a vaccine that has received WHO emergency use listing (or one dose for Johnson & Johnson). From 1 November 2022 a traveller will only be considered fully vaccinated if they have had a booster shot or received their second dose not more than three (3) months prior.
Brunei will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
column5:
Latest News:

International Resrictions:
*Entry to Brunei: Entry to Brunei is restricted. Land and sea borders are currently closed. On 22 April 2022, Brunei announced a further easing of restrictions for inbound and outbound travellers.
From 6 May 2022, Brunei will no longer categorise countries and will allow fully vaccinated passengers to make non-essential travel by air to and from any countries without requiring an Entry Travel Pass. (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 status below for definition of fully vaccinated).
Fully-vaccinated travellers entering Brunei must take an ART upon arrival (Day 1), and again on Day 2 and Day 3 after arriving in Brunei. Self-isolation is no longer required if the ART results are negative. You must pay $40 BND for the three ART kits given to you on arrival.
Travellers who are not fully-vaccinated are only permitted to enter Brunei if they can verify that they are medically exempted from receiving a COVID-19 vaccination. Unvaccinated travellers will need to follow the non-Travel Green List Countries travel protocols (see Entry from a non-green list country below).
They are required to perform an ART upon arrival and RT-PCR test on Day 3. They are also required to undergo self-isolation until a negative RT-PCR result is obtained. Travellers will be charged $100 BND for both ART and RT-PCR.
See the Brunei Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) website for further information, or contact the Brunei High Commission.
Travellers from countries not listed on the Green list must take an ART upon arrival and then self-isolate (see Quarantine). They must undergo a COVID-19 RT-PCR test on Day 5 at a designated swab centre (day of arrival is considered Day 1). COVID-19 recovered travellers are only required to undergo ART upon arrival (at a fee of B$20.00).
All travellers into Brunei must;
• be fully vaccinated with 2 doses unless they can show proof of a medical exemption from having the COVID-19 vaccination (under 18s travelling with a group of vaccinated adults will follow the vaccinated protocols)
• submit an Arrival Declaration form on the PMO travel portal no more than 24 hours prior to departure.
• download and register on the BruHealth App prior to departure (see Data Collection).
• make payment for the relevant post arrival COVID tests depending on your vaccination or recovery status and obtain a payment receipt which states the name and passport number of the traveller
• show to their airline at check-in a negative COVID-19 RT PCR test obtained within 48 hours of departure, or an ART obtained within 24 hours of departure (those with recovery certificates do not need to do a pre-departure test). You should arrange to take a private test
Foreign nationals entering Brunei for a short visit (less than 90 days) are required to obtain Travel Insurance with COVID-19 medical coverage (a minimum of $50,000 BND). Foreign nationals entering for the purpose of employment, studying or as eligible dependent are exempted from this requirement
From 1 October 2020, all travellers entering Brunei via a land border will need to pay $3 BND per person on exit and $3 BND on return or entry. You should refer to the Prime Minister’s Office website for the latest information.
Travellers who have recently had COVID
From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempt from providing a pre-travel negative COVID-19 test and will only have to take an ART on arrival. They must have a certificate as proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 90 days.
*Demonstrating your COVID-19 status: To enter Brunei, a traveller is considered fully vaccinated if they have received two doses of a vaccine that has received WHO emergency use listing (or one dose for Johnson & Johnson). From 1 November 2022 a traveller will only be considered fully vaccinated if they have had a booster shot or received their second dose not more than three (3) months prior.
Brunei will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
*Quarantine requirements: From 6 May onwards, fully vaccinated visitors to Brunei from will not need to isolate on arrival. Only unvaccinated travellers will need to undergo self-isolation at a suitable accommodation (home residence or hotel accommodation) until their receive a negative result for the post arrival RT-PCR test.
From 1 April 2022, travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 90 days will be exempted from undergoing mandatory self-isolation. They must provide proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 90 days.
Data collection On arrival in Brunei, it is mandatory to use the BruHealth app to record test results, record your health status on a daily basis and to enter public buildings and events where you need to scan a QR code. Failure to do so may result in financial penalties and legal repercussions, additionally you not being able to access public buildings.
*Exiting Brunei: From 1 April 2022, travellers exiting Brunei (for any destination) no longer require a travel permit. Citizens and residents who wish to travel are required to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19, with the second dose administered not more than 3 months prior to departure or have received a booster dose. From 15 May this will apply to 12 - 17 year olds too. Unvaccinated passengers will only be permitted to travel if they have a certificate of medical exemption from vaccination or of having recovered from COVID in the past 90 days.
Brunei citizens and permanent residents are required to obtain a Travel Medical Insurance with COVID-19 coverage (a minimum coverage of $50,000 BND) valid for the entire duration of their travel.
From 1 October 2020, all travellers exiting Brunei via a land border will need to pay $3 BND per person on exit and $3 BND on return or entry. A permit for land border travel is still banned and will require a special permit. You should refer to the Prime Minister’s Office website for the latest information.


Internal Restrictions:
*Coronavirus lockdown: Brunei went into lockdown on 7 August 2021. Although measures have since relaxed, there are still restrictions in place.
As part of Brunei’s National COVID-19 Recovery Framework, Brunei moved to its “early endemic phase” on 15 December until 31 May 2022. Business premises, including restaurants, fitness facilities, markets and cinemas can open at 75% capacity or 300 people, whichever is the lower number. Social gatherings at home are limited to 30 people only, and all attendees must take an Antigen Rapid Test (ART).
Child care centres, kindergartens, secondary schools, colleges and sixth form centres resumed classroom learning on 5 April. International primary schools re-opened for in person classes on 12 April and public primary schools will return to in person classes on 14 May 2022. Students must take an ART three times a week.
All individuals, regardless of vaccination status are now allowed to enter public premises and government offices and attend private and public events. Unvaccinated adults must take an ART, the results of which will be valid for 2 days. Unvaccinated under 18’s will be exempt from taking an ART test if they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.
Brunei will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
You should expect to have your temperature taken, electronically, and must check-in to business premises and government offices using the BruHealth app.
Masks are mandatory for everyone over 2 years old when in public places indoors, but may be removed when you are drinking or eating, or if you are exercising. There are financial penalties for not adhering to mask guidelines. Masks are not mandatory outdoors if you are exercising, walking alone or with your immediate household in an uncrowded area.
British people travelling should check the Brunei Ministry of Health and the Prime Ministers Office websites for up to date guidance, policy on travel to/from Brunei and details on how to download and use the BruHealth app.
